The Lakeland High football program has been impacted by a COVID-19 case that will require the program to suspend all operations for the next two weeks.

As a precaution, the program is following CDC-recommended guidance from the Florida Department of Health in Polk County, and will suspend all operations through Sept. 22.

Lakeland High’s first two games of the season (against George Jenkins and Plant City) have been canceled; at this time, it is unlikely the games will be rescheduled.

Due to privacy and medical records laws, Polk County Public Schools cannot identify anyone who has tested positive, or provide additional details about the COVID-19 case impacting LHS football.

Alta Vista Elementary has plenty to buzz about this year.

For starters, the school received a branding makeover this summer with new colors and an updated mascot, Avie the Hornet.

Avie is quickly becoming the face of the school, appearing on signage and safety reminders throughout campus. Principal Celeste Stewart doesn't seem to mind.

"The kids love it. We talk about Avie all the time," Stewart said. "We just took (the new look) and ran with it."

No offense to Avie, but an even more popular addition is the school's long-awaited new playground, decked out in Alta Vista's new colors.

"Great things are happening here," Stewart said.

Creating a districtwide eSchool (online school) option has been a major undertaking this year. Although we did encounter some issues last week, we also received some nice feedback from parents who said they're embracing and enjoying the eSchool life.

Courtney Farlow is an intern from Polk State College Teacher Education, and she's already leaving her mark on our schools.

We mean that literally.

This past Sunday was National Book Lovers Day, and it reminded us of one student in particular who we've been overdue in recognizing.

George Sapp clearly loves to read. Last year at Spessard Holland Elementary, the fifth-grader racked up an astounding 2,020.3 Accelerated Reader (AR) points.

To put it into perspective, an especially skilled and dedicated reader might earn 500 to 700 AR points in a year. Surpassing 1,000 points or more is rare territory.

We don't keep records at the district level, but our staff suspect that George's 2,020.3 points might be a single-year record for PCPS. George's family said he earned a total 3,161.2 AR points during his elementary school career.

"George Sapp is one amazing young man with such determination," said Spessard Holland Principal Melody Butler. "He's an amazing scholar. We are so proud of him."

George is moving on to Union Academy this year. We wish him well on his next chapter.

#LovePolkSchools

The Polk County School Board meeting scheduled for Tuesday, June 30, has been postponed until a later date.

The meeting was called for the purpose of discussing the upcoming superintendent search and allowing the public to have input.

The meeting was structured to comply with CDC guidance, including allowing board members to participate virtually, limiting the capacity of rooms, requiring social distancing, making masks available to attendees, and prohibiting attendance by individuals who have been exposed, tested positive, or exhibit symptoms of COVID-19.

However, Health Department concerns about widespread transmission in Polk County, transmission among younger groups, and transmission by individuals without symptoms resulted in a decision to postpone the meeting until a later date to be determined.

We will provide an update once more information is available. You can view the School Board meeting calendar and other info at polkschoolsfl.com/meetings.

Our graduates deserved a celebration of their accomplishments, and that’s what we gave them. Today will live in the memories of our graduates forever, and when they look back, I hope that’s what they remember: to never, ever give up, no matter how difficult things become.”

At Fort Meade High, each year's graduating class leaves their mark with a mural. The Class of 2020 was able to maintain that tradition, even while campuses were closed in the midst of a pandemic.

The new mural -- which features a gas mask, virus particles and rolls of toilet paper -- is reflective of the strange and scary times that inspired it. But the seniors who produced the artwork say it has been a highlight of a difficult year.

"At first I was very sad because we lost the last months of our senior year, and those are the best times," said Halee Shaver, senior class vice president. "I think the mural was one thing that helped me, because I realized that our traditions aren’t going anywhere, they just have to be done differently."

After Rachel's mom told her about the encounter, she sent her teacher an email: "Every time I paint or color I think about you. Miss you so much! Maybe see you soon."

"I arranged with her mom for me to stop by with some of my sidewalk chalk," Syrakis said. "She was so excited. She asked if we could do the rose from 'Beauty and the Beast.'"

"And so we did."

A new 10-month study highlights how Polk County Public Schools can better support students who are struggling academically and have social, emotional and behavioral needs.

The study included visits to schools throughout the district, as well as in-person interviews and focus groups with hundreds of teachers, administrators, district personnel, students, parents and other stakeholders.

“We are always looking for ways to better serve our students and become a more efficient educational system,” said Superintendent Jacqueline Byrd.

“I greatly appreciate everyone who took time to share their thoughts and participate in this extensive study. Thanks to your help, we can see our areas of strength and, more importantly, target opportunities for improvement. Together we can better support our struggling learners and ensure all of our students live up to their full potential.”

See highlights from the study and access the complete document at https://tinyurl.com/y96shsqe.

We’re thankful for the mobile food pantry serving our students and families at Crystal Lake Elementary.

Crystal Lake Elementary is Polk County’s first community partnership school, serving as a convenient location where students, their families and local residents can access a wide variety of education, health care and social service resources.

What happens when you challenge a group of housebound elementary school students to recreate famous works of art?

In the case of Scott Lake Elementary, you get these funny and fascinating masterpieces.

"Napoleon Crossing the Alps" becomes "Connor Crossing the Back Yard on a Stuffed Unicorn."

"Portrait of a Man in a Red Turban" is remade as "Andrew Wearing a Rather Nice Bath Towel."

"American Gothic" gets a Shovel Edition update -- because who owns a pitchfork anymore?

"In the classroom, I have very high standards for my students, and they have been meeting the mark and surpassing it during distance learning," says Kristi Robinson, a visual arts teacher at Scott Lake Elementary. "Being able to break out of the classroom setting box has truly been the silver lining. Seeing them put themselves inside the artwork and enjoying art in a new way has been exciting and rewarding."

Magnifique!

#LovePolkSchools

Hey, slow down for a second!

Don't forget that tomorrow (Friday, April 10) is a regularly scheduled holiday for students and staff, so district offices and schools will be closed (even more than usual lately).

Beginning Monday (April 13), we will transition to a new schedule at our food distribution sites, which will be open three days per week (Monday, Wednesday and Friday) from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Due to staffing constraints related to the coronavirus, we also will be operating fewer meal sites, so please check polkschoolsfl.com/lunchlocations before you head out.

We hope you have a great weekend. Please try to stay home, stay safe and take care of each other.

(Photo via Sleepy Hill Elementary School.)

Three of our teachers got together for an online discussion about distance learning -- which has been a new and often challenging experience for students and staff alike.

Watch the story at the link below. Thanks to Jennifer Horvatin from Highland City Elementary, Erin Lavelle from Lawton Chiles Middle Academy, and PCPS Teacher of the Year Dr. Vincent Miller from Winter Haven High.

Some of the takeaways from our educators: Distance learning is new for everyone, and we're all trying to work through it together. Try to maintain good communication with your child's teachers to help with your child's distance learning plan.

Don't forget, PCPS now has a help line for technology issues related to distance learning. You can call 863-614-1600 on weekdays from 8:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. More info here: https://tinyurl.com/rp7dxwm.

Highland City Elementary School
Lawton Chiles Middle Academy
